key_points: Colonial Pipeline had not undergone a voluntary, in-depth cybersecurity review with the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) before a ransomware attack impacted its operations.
The ransomware attack forced Colonial Pipeline to shut down its pipeline, causing fuel shortages across the East Coast.
Officials are concerned that the lack of a cybersecurity review left critical infrastructure vulnerable to attacks.
The Department of Homeland Security is moving towards implementing mandatory rules for pipeline cybersecurity after decades of voluntary guidelines.
The TSA has historically partnered with the energy industry to set voluntary cybersecurity guidelines, without penalties for non-compliance.
Only 23 comprehensive cybersecurity assessments (VADR) were conducted by the TSA on pipeline companies as of late 2018.
Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas emphasized the importance of adapting to new and emerging threats in cybersecurity.
Colonial Pipeline has reportedly increased its IT spending by about 50% since 2017, hiring independent firms for cybersecurity risk assessments.
The shift to mandatory cybersecurity measures comes amid growing ransomware attacks on critical infrastructure.
Despite the authority to enforce mandatory rules, the TSA has relied on voluntary compliance, influenced by industry resistance to regulation.
spokespersons: Rep. Jim Langevin (D-R.I., Co-founder of the Congressional Cybersecurity Caucus)
Michael Chertoff (Former Secretary of Homeland Security)
